title: 111_s2983
content: The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" is a legislation that provides payroll tax forgiveness for hiring unemployed workers. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for certain individuals hired in 2010, where wages paid by a qualified employer to a qualified individual are exempt from taxes for services performed during a specific period. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for qualified employers hiring individuals after February 3, 2010, and before January 1, 2011. Qualified individuals must certify they have not worked more than 40 hours in the 60-day period before starting employment. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" offers an exemption for qualified employers hiring individuals between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011. Qualified individuals must not have worked over 40 hours in the 60-day period before starting employment. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude wages paid to qualified individuals by qualified employers from payroll taxes for a 1-year period. Appropriations are made to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund to offset revenue reductions. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude wages paid to qualified individuals by qualified employers from payroll taxes for a 1-year period. Appropriations are made to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund to offset revenue reductions. The amendments made by this section shall apply to wages paid after the date of the enactment of this Act. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a business credit for retaining certain newly hired individuals in 2010. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" offers a business credit for retaining qualified individuals for at least 52 consecutive weeks with wages for the last 26 weeks. To qualify for the business credit under the "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010," an individual must have been employed by the taxpayer for a minimum of 52 consecutive weeks, with wages in the last 26 weeks equaling at least 80 percent of the wages in the first 26 weeks.
